questions.text:
A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing fatigue for the past 1 month. He has been unable to do normal household duties or go for his evening walks during this period. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. His father died of liver cancer at the age of 60 years. He does not smoke. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, metformin, and insulin glargine. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 116/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.6 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
87 μm3



Leukocyte count
9700/mm3



Platelet count
182,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
213 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL


 Albumin
4.1 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
1.1 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
66 U/L


 AST
100 U/L


 ALT
69 U/L


 γ-Glutamyl transferase
28 U/L (N = 5–50)


 Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


 Hepatitis C antibody
negative


 Iron studies



 Iron
261 μg/dL


 Ferritin

558 ng/mL


 Transferrin saturation


83% (N = 20–50)


 Anti-nuclear antibody
negative


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan or MRI of the abdomen may reveal evidence of iron overload but cannot differentiate primary from secondary iron overload, so a different investigation is required to confirm the diagnosis of HH. In patients with HH, a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen can be used to evaluate for hepatocellular carcinoma if a nodule > 1 cm is detected on a screening abdominal ultrasound.

B) INCORRECT:

A bone marrow biopsy is indicated if sideroblastic anemia is suspected. This condition manifests with microcytic anemia despite an iron overload, and the iron overload in sideroblastic anemia is less severe (serum ferritin levels are typically not more than 300 ng/mL).

C) INCORRECT:

Because patients with HH who develop cirrhosis have a 20–30% lifetime risk and 3–4% annual risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma, they should undergo screening ultrasonography every 6 months once cirrhosis develops. However, ultrasonography of the abdomen cannot confirm the diagnosis of HH. It also has a low sensitivity (∼ 40%) for the diagnosis of cirrhosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy was previously considered the best initial test for diagnosing HH. This test has largely been replaced by a less invasive and more specific test. In patients with confirmed HH, a liver biopsy is performed to stage the degree of fibrosis or cirrhosis and is only indicated if serum ferritin levels are > 1000 ng/mL (since the risk of cirrhosis is low if ferritin levels are below this value) and/or if AST/ALT levels are significantly elevated.

E) CORRECT:

Genetic testing is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis of HH, identify the specific genetic mutations involved, and guide management (e.g., the frequency of phlebotomy) and family screening. Genetic testing is indicated if the patient has evidence of iron overload on serum iron studies and/or has a first-degree relative with HH. HFE gene mutations, particularly C282Y and H63D mutations, are the most common cause of HH. Homozygous C282Y mutations result in clinically significant HH while a compound heterozygous mutation (C282Y/H63D) is associated with a milder disease phenotype with a low risk of complications. HH caused by non-HFE mutations is rare but severe and requires aggressive management.
questions.hint: In an adult patient with a family history of hepatocellular carcinoma, the presence of generalized fatigue, diabetes mellitus, hepatomegaly, laboratory evidence of iron overload (serum ferritin > 200 ng/mL among men or > 150 ng/mL among women, serum transferrin saturation ≥ 45%) suggest a primary iron overload, also known as hereditary hemochromatosis (HH).

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and progressive pain and stiffness in her hands for the past 3 months. She used to play tennis but stopped 1 month ago because of difficulties holding the racket. Her last menstrual period was 1 year ago. She has diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows generalized hyperpigmentation. The range of motion of the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands is limited. Serum anti-nuclear antibody titers are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum uric acid levels support the diagnosis of gout, which also presents with arthralgia. However, acute gouty arthritis typically causes acute excruciating pain, redness, and warmth of a single joint, and often occurs after an inciting event (e.g., heavy alcohol consumption), none of which is present in this patient. This patient's arthropathy is most likely due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Although calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease is a likely complication of this patient's condition, serum calcium levels are typically normal in this condition and would not help confirm the cause of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

A dorsopalmar x-ray of this patient's hands would likely reveal chondrocalcinosis and degenerative changes such as joint space narrowing, subchondral cysts, and the formation of hook-shaped osteophytes at the metacarpal heads. However, these changes are nonspecific and would not confirm the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's arthropathy is most likely due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), and arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis might reveal calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals. However, synovial fluid analysis would not disclose the underlying cause of CPPD.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of fatigue, symmetric arthralgias affecting the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, skin hyperpigmentation, and diabetes mellitus suggests hemochromatosis. In premenopausal women, iron loss from menstruation can delay disease progression. In a menopausal woman like this patient, however, hemochromatosis will cause iron accumulation in multiple organs, causing symptoms as seen here. Iron studies in this patient will most likely show increased serum iron, serum ferritin, and transferrin saturation. For patients with confirmed iron overload, genetic testing for mutations of the HFE gene is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of hereditary hemochromatosis.

This patient's amenorrhea is likely to be explained by menopause as she is 51 years old, which is the average age of U.S. women at the time of menopause. Hemochromatosis itself can also lead to amenorrhea in premenopausal women because of iron-induced damage to the pituitary gland and/or gonads.

F) INCORRECT:

Testing for rheumatoid factor is performed in the screening for numerous rheumatological diseases, predominantly rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Symmetric arthralgias, stiffness in the metacarpophalangeal joints, and fatigue are common features of RA. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of RA, such as wrist and interphalangeal joint involvement, and RA would not explain this patient's skin hyperpigmentation and diabetes mellitus.
Image Description:

Symmetrical swelling of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints.
questions.hint: This patient's underlying condition puts her at increased risk for cardiomyopathy, liver cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old White man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and leg swelling for the past 4 months. He has to pause several times when climbing one flight of stairs. For the past 10 years, he has had joint pain in his hands, wrists, and knees. He has diabetes mellitus and hypertension controlled with daily insulin injections and a strict low-calorie, low-sodium diet. He takes ibuprofen as needed for his joint pain. His wife says that he snores at night. He drinks two to three beers daily. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He visited his daughter in northern New York one month ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, pitting edema around the ankles, and generalized cutaneous hyperpigmentation. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. An S3 is heard at the apex. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. An ECG shows a left bundle branch block. Echocardiography shows left atrial and ventricular enlargement, reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, and mild mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Nocturnal continuous positive airway pressure therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking is an important risk factor for cardiomyopathy resulting from coronary artery disease. However, this patient's additional symptoms suggest a different etiology for his heart failure. While smoking cessation should be recommended for all patients, it would not have prevented his condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can contribute to heart failure (especially if pulmonary hypertension is present) and is associated with increased cardiovascular mortality, as well as with diabetes and hepatic steatosis. While this patient's history of snoring could suggest underlying OSA, his other symptoms and the absence of treatment-resistant hypertension suggest a different etiology of heart failure, and using nocturnal CPAP would not have prevented his condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic alcohol abuse can cause dilated cardiomyopathy, but this patient's additional symptoms are more suggestive of an alternative etiology of heart failure. Although he should be counseled on reducing his alcohol intake, it would not have prevented his condition.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's mitral regurgitation is likely due to the dilated cardiomyopathy (from left ventricular dilatation and stretching of the mitral annulus), rather than the cause of the cardiomyopathy. Repairing the mitral valve is not indicated and would not have prevented his condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Losartan is used both for the treatment of hypertension and HFrEF. Angiotensin-inhibiting medications are indicated for all patients with HFrEF as these drugs improve prognosis. Although this patient should now be started on an ARB or an ACEI, it would not have prevented his condition.

F) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of multiorgan involvement: dilated cardiomyopathy, arthritis (usually symmetrical, oligoarticular, progresses to chondrocalcinosis), hepatomegaly, hyperpigmented skin, and diabetes (bronze diabetes). These features indicate a diagnosis of hereditary hemochromatosis (primary iron overload), which is the most frequent genetic disease in the White population. Regular phlebotomy to deplete iron stores is the treatment of choice for patients with hereditary hemochromatosis. After confirming the diagnosis, therapeutic phlebotomy should be started immediately in patients with symptomatic disease or evidence of iron overload (serum ferritin > 1000 ng/mL), as this can reverse early left ventricular systolic dysfunction and minimize damage to other organs.

G) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease, a tick-borne infection caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, can cause arthritis and carditis. Lyme carditis, while very rare, typically manifests with conduction abnormalities (e.g, AV node block), and there are only isolated case reports of it causing dilated cardiomyopathy. Although this patient was recently in an endemic area, the duration and combination of his other symptoms suggest a different etiology, and wearing protective clothing would not have prevented his condition.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of heart failure, and echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy. This patient's additional symptoms suggest a specific underlying cause.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasing fatigue and reduced libido. He also complains of joint pain in both of his hands. He has a history of hypertension that is controlled with enalapril. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. He drinks 2–3 beers on the weekends. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows diffuse hyperpigmentation and decreased size of the testes. The second and third metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are tender to palpation, and range of motion is limited. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Serum studies show:


Ferritin
340 ng/mL


Aspartate aminotransferase
70 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase
80 U/L


Glucose
250 mg/dL


This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can occur in association with infections (e.g., EBV, HCV, Helicobacter pylori), autoimmune diseases (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis), and dermatomyositis. However, an association between non-Hodgkin lymphoma and hemochromatosis is less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Hereditary syndromes such as familial adenomatous polyposis and Lynch syndrome are genetic risk factors for colorectal adenocarcinoma. Although some studies suggest an increased risk of colorectal cancer in hemochromatosis, this association is not well established and other complications are more likely to occur.

C) CORRECT:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the most serious complications and the most common cause of death in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis. The risk of HCC in these patients is increased 20–200 fold compared to the general population. HCC arises from progressive iron deposition in the hepatic parenchyma that results in cirrhosis. Patients with hereditary hemochromatosis and advanced cirrhosis should be actively screened for HCC.

D) INCORRECT:

Parkinsonism is a common finding in Wilson disease because of copper accumulation in the basal ganglia. Wilson disease manifests with hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases, but arthralgia, hyperpigmentation, hypogonadism, and elevated ferritin levels are not expected and are more suggestive of hemochromatosis. In hemochromatosis, iron does not usually accumulate in the basal ganglia but rather in the pituitary gland, resulting in hypopituitarism.

E) INCORRECT:

Progressive central obesity can be caused by endocrine changes, such as increased cortisol in Cushing syndrome. While hemochromatosis can cause various endocrine changes (due to iron accumulation in various organs), like diabetes mellitus and/or hypopituitarism, none of these changes leads to progressive central obesity.

F) INCORRECT:

Although hemochromatosis causes arthralgia in joints that are commonly affected in rheumatoid arthritis (e.g., metacarpophalangeal joints), patients with this condition are not at increased risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis.

G) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic cancer is associated with several inherited genetic syndromes, such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, Lynch syndrome, and multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. However, the link between pancreatic cancer and hemochromatosis is not well established.
questions.hint: This patient presents with liver disease (hepatomegaly, transaminitis), hypogonadism (loss of libido, testicular atrophy), diabetes mellitus (hyperglycemia), diffuse hyperpigmentation, and joint disease. These features in conjunction with elevated ferritin are suggestive of hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasing fatigue and reduced libido. He also complains of joint pain in both of his hands. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows small testes. The second and third metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are tender to palpation and range of motion is limited. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin. Histopathologic examination of a liver biopsy specimen shows intracellular material that stains with Prussian blue. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Many risk factors exist for colorectal carcinoma, including genetic syndromes (such as familial adenomatous polyposis and HNPCC), inflammatory bowel disease, tobacco use, and a low-fiber diet. Although some studies suggest an increased risk of colorectal cancer in patients with hemochromatosis, this association is not well established and other complications are more likely to occur.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with untreated or advanced hemochromatosis, iron deposition in cardiac tissues and subsequent fibrosis can lead to either restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy. Iron deposition in cardiac tissues can also lead to cardiac conduction abnormalities and arrhythmias. Patients with hemochromatosis are also at a significantly higher risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) when compared to the general population. HCC is the most common cause of death in patients with hemochromatosis.
Image Description:

Left: Iron homeostasis is regulated by the HFE gene. HFE regulates levels of hepcidin, a protein that reduces the transport of iron from the cells to the bloodstream via the ferroportin transport protein.

Right: Hemochromatosis results from the mutation of the HFE gene → reduced hepcidin production → unregulated ferroportin activity → iron accumulation throughout the body → end-organ damage

C) INCORRECT:

Known risk factors for rheumatoid arthritis include being female, genetic predisposition (HLA-DR4 has been implicated), and smoking. Hemochromatosis is not a risk factor for rheumatoid arthritis, but is associated with the development of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease and irreversible arthropathy, especially affecting the MCP joints (as seen in this patient).

D) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for pancreatic adenocarcinoma include certain genetic syndromes (e.g., Peutz-Jeghers syndrome), tobacco use, chronic pancreatitis, and diabetes. There is no known link between hemochromatosis and pancreatic cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for NHL include infections (e.g., EBV, HCV, Helicobacter pylori), autoimmune diseases (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis), and dermatomyositis. There is no known association between hemochromatosis and the development of NHL.
questions.hint: Testicular atrophy, hepatomegaly, and siderosis with Prussian blue staining are all suggestive of hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, darkening of her skin, and pain in her ankle joints. She has also had increased thirst and frequent urination for 2 weeks. She receives approximately 5 blood transfusions every year; her last transfusion was 3 months ago. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented skin, scleral icterus, pale mucous membranes, and a liver span of 17 cm. Which of the following serum findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepcidin is an iron-regulatory protein that impairs iron absorption in the intestinal mucosa and decreases iron release from macrophages. As an acute-phase reactant, it mediates anemia of chronic disease in patients with chronic inflammation. Deficiency of hepcidin is thought to cause hemochromatosis, resulting in primary iron overload. Hepcidin levels have also been shown to be suppressed or not detectable in patients with thalassemia, showing that secondary iron overload in this condition is not only due to frequent blood transfusions but also results from increased iron absorption in the intestine.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with beta-thalassemia major who undergo frequent blood transfusions are prone to developing secondary iron overload due to the high iron content of red blood cells. Plasma ferritin is a marker of total body iron stores and would thus be elevated in this patient. Other expected findings are decreased transferrin/TIBC levels and elevated transferrin saturation.

C) INCORRECT:

Transferrin saturation, which indicates how much of the circulating transferrin is bound to iron, directly increases with serum iron levels. This patient who receives frequent blood transfusions likely developed secondary iron overload, which results in increased transferrin saturation.

D) INCORRECT:

Transferrin is an iron transport protein, whose levels vary inversely with total body iron stores. This patient who receives frequent blood transfusions likely developed secondary iron overload, which results in decreased transferrin levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Haptoglobin is an acute-phase reactant that binds to free hemoglobin released into the circulation and would thus be decreased in intravascular hemolysis. Since thalassemia predominantly causes extravascular hemolysis (occurs in the reticuloendothelial system), haptoglobin levels would not be significantly affected.

F) INCORRECT:

The total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) reflects the blood's capacity to bind iron with transferrin and hence is an indirect measurement of transferrin. This patient who receives frequent blood transfusions likely developed secondary iron overload. As a result, most of her transferrin is already bound to iron and her capacity to bind further iron is decreased.
questions.hint: This patient's fatigue, joint pain, hyperpigmented skin, signs of diabetes mellitus (e.g., polydipsia, polyuria), hepatomegaly, and history of beta-thalassemia major with frequent blood transfusions are highly suggestive of secondary hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with β-thalassemia major comes to the physician with a 1-week history of fatigue. She receives approximately 8 blood transfusions per year; her last transfusion was 1 month ago. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Her hemoglobin level is 6.5 mg/dL. Microscopic evaluation of a liver biopsy specimen in this patient would most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Macrophages with cytoplasmic granules that stain golden-yellow with hematoxylin
Cytoplasmic brown-pigmented granules that stain positive for S-100
Cytoplasmic pink-staining granules that stain positive with PAS

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing macrophages with yellow-brown, lipid-containing granules describes lipofuscin deposits, which accumulate with increasing age in several organs such as the heart and neurons. Pathologically increased deposition of lipofuscin is implicated in the pathogenesis of various diseases, including macular degeneration, neurocognitive disorders like Alzheimer disease, and various lysosomal storage diseases. However, it is not associated with iron overload.

B) CORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing macrophages with cytoplasmic granules that stain golden-yellow with hematoxylin describes hemosiderin deposits. These often occur in the setting of chronic iron overload, as seen in this patient. Recurrent blood transfusions stimulate increased hemolysis with subsequent phagocytosis of hemoglobin by macrophages, thereby promoting hemosiderin accumulation. In severe cases, secondary hemochromatosis eventually develops. This patient's biopsy sample would also stain brightly with Prussian blue, which identifies intracellular iron.

C) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing extracellular deposition of pink-staining proteins is characteristic of amyloid proteins, which can accumulate in the setting of localized or systemic amyloidosis. Amyloid proteins can best be visualized with congo-red stain and develop either in response to chronic inflammatory or infectious conditions or idiopathically as primary amyloidosis. However, neither thalassemia nor chronic transfusion therapy is associated with the development of secondary amyloidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing cytoplasmic brown-pigmented granules that stain positive for S-100 would be consistent with metastatic melanoma. However, because this patient does not have a history of suspicious skin lesions or previously diagnosed melanoma, metastatic melanoma is highly unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy showing cytoplasmic pink-staining granules that stain positive with PAS indicate deposition of excess sugars. This finding is typically observed in patients with glycogen storage diseases but not in those receiving chronic blood transfusions.
questions.hint: Individuals requiring recurrent blood transfusions are susceptible to an iron overload state.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 44 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: White, self-identified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I am thirsty all the time, and it's getting worse.”
History of Present Illness:


6-month history of increased thirst

has had to urinate more frequently for 4 months; urinates every 3–4 hours

feels generally weaker and more tired than usual
has also had a 1-year history of joint pain in the hands

Past Medical History:

gastroesophageal reflux disease
tension headaches

Medications:
pantoprazole, amitriptyline, multivitamin
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial History:

has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years

occasionally drinks two or three beers on weekends
used to be sexually active with his husband but has been losing interest in sexual activity for the past 6 months


Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.2°C(99.0°F)
78/min
16/min
127/77 mm Hg
–
188 cm(6 ft 2 in) 
85 kg(187 lb)
24 kg/m2




Appearance: no acute distress
HEENT: sclerae anicteric; no oropharyngeal erythema or exudate
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: no tenderness, guarding, masses, or bruits; the liver span is 15 cm

Pelvic: small, firm testes; no nodules or masses
Extremities: tenderness to palpation and stiffness of the metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands

Skin: diffusely hyperpigmented

Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits


This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis can occur in patients with carcinoid syndrome, which manifests with secretory diarrhea, episodic flushing, and wheezing; it is not associated with manifestations of diabetes (e.g., polydipsia, polyuria), arthralgias, hyperpigmented skin, testicular atrophy, or hepatomegaly. Valvular heart disease due to iron deposition in the valves is a rare complication of hemochromatosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal vein thrombosis is typically associated with nephrotic syndrome and other hypercoagulable states (e.g., antiphospholipid syndrome, factor V Leiden mutation), not hemochromatosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysms are typically associated with conditions such as Kawasaki disease, Takayasu arteritis, polyarteritis nodosa, connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome), and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Although hemochromatosis is associated with an increased risk of atherosclerosis (due to iron-induced oxidative stress), coronary artery aneurysms are not a common complication of hemochromatosis.

D) CORRECT:

Hemochromatosis causes iron deposition in the cardiac conduction system, which can lead to a variety of conduction abnormalities. These include sinus node dysfunction, complete AV block, atrial and ventricular tachyarrythmias, and rarely, sudden cardiac death. The most common arrhythmia observed in patients with hemochromatosis is paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Other common cardiac complications include dilated cardiomyopathy, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and heart failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Temporal artery inflammation is typically caused by giant cell arteritis, which typically manifests in women > 50 years with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss) and headaches. This condition is not associated with manifestations of diabetes (e.g., polydipsia, polyuria), arthralgias, hyperpigmented skin, testicular atrophy, or hepatomegaly. Hemochromatosis is not associated with temporal artery inflammation.
questions.hint: This patient's manifestations of diabetes mellitus (e.g., polyuria, polydipsia), arthralgias, hyperpigmented skin, testicular atrophy, and hepatomegaly are highly suspicious for a diagnosis of hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 1 month. He has been unable to practice with his recreational soccer team and has had to rest frequently when walking to work. His only medication is ibuprofen for joint pain. Physical examination shows tanned skin. There is tenderness to palpation and stiffness of the metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. Pulmonary examination shows coarse crackles in both lung fields. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing is most likely to be positive for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 is associated with seronegative arthritides (i.e., inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis), which can cause joint pain and fatigue. This patient does not have gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, abdominal pain) that raise suspicion for an underlying inflammatory bowel disease. Ankylosing spondylitis is a form of arthritis that primarily affects the axial skeleton (e.g., spine, sacroiliac joint) rather than the small joints of the hands. In the other seronegative arthritides, the distal joints are most commonly involved but are affected asymmetrically (in contrast to this patient, who has symmetrical arthropathy). Moreover, this patient does not have psoriatic lesions or a history of recent genitourinary infection to suggest a diagnosis of these other seronegative arthritides.

B) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR3 is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Addison disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), Hashimoto thyroiditis, and Graves disease. SLE can cause fatigue, symmetrical small joint arthropathy, postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (due to photosensitivity), and dyspnea with crackles due to lung or heart involvement. However, it does not cause hepatomegaly and more commonly occurs among women. Addison disease, T1DM, and Hashimoto thyroiditis can cause fatigue; in addition, Addison disease causes hyperpigmentation, and Hashimoto thyroiditis can cause joint pain. However, this patient does not have other characteristic features of these conditions (e.g., weight loss, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms in Addison disease; weight loss and polyuria in T1DM; goiter and weight gain in Hashimoto thyroiditis). None of these conditions cause hepatomegaly or crackles. Graves disease causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, heat intolerance), which are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), Addison disease, and type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). RA causes metacarpophalangeal (MCP) arthropathy and fatigue. Dyspnea with crackles can also occur in patients RA as a result of lung involvement. However, RA does not cause cutaneous hyperpigmentation and more commonly occurs among women. In addition, hepatomegaly is not a typical initial manifestation of RA. Addison disease causes fatigue and diffuse hyperpigmentation, but it does not cause MCP arthropathy, hepatomegaly, or pulmonary manifestations; in addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of Addison disease, such as weight loss, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms. T1DM can cause fatigue, but it typically manifests before 30 years of age and is associated with additional symptoms, such as weight loss and polyuria, which are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

HLA-B8 is associated with Addison disease, myasthenia gravis, and Graves disease. Addison disease causes fatigue and hyperpigmentation but does not cause arthropathy, hepatomegaly, or pulmonary manifestations. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of Addison disease, such as weight loss, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Myasthenia gravis can cause fatigue and dyspnea (due to diaphragmatic weakness), but it does not cause arthropathy, crackles, hepatomegaly, or hyperpigmentation. Graves disease causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, heat intolerance), which are not seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

HLA-A3 is associated with hereditary hemochromatosis (HH), which is caused by an autosomal recessive HFE gene defect that leads to abnormal iron sensing and increased intestinal iron absorption. The clinical features of HH are caused by organ iron overload. Iron deposition in the heart can lead to either dilated or restrictive cardiomyopathy. Deposition in the skin causes hyperpigmentation. Accumulation of iron in the joints leads to articular damage and promotes calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition; the metacarpophalangeal joints are classically involved. Deposition in the liver leads to hepatomegaly, cirrhosis, and increased risk for hepatocellular carcinoma, which is the most common cause of death in patients with HH. Other manifestations of HH include diabetes mellitus and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Image Description:

Left: Iron homeostasis is regulated by the HFE gene. HFE regulates levels of hepcidin, a protein that reduces the transport of iron from the cells to the bloodstream via the ferroportin transport protein.

Right: Hemochromatosis results from the mutation of the HFE gene → reduced hepcidin production → unregulated ferroportin activity → iron accumulation throughout the body → end-organ damage
questions.hint: This patient has features of heart failure (e.g., fatigue, exertional dyspnea, coarse crackles in both lung fields). These findings, in addition to cutaneous hyperpigmentation, hepatomegaly, and joint pain, are suspicious for a diagnosis of hemochromatosis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man with a history of beta-thalassemia, secondary hemochromatosis related to repeated blood transfusions, iron overload cardiomyopathy, and a previously documented left ventricular ejection fraction of 37% returns for evaluation. He currently takes furosemide, metoprolol succinate, and lisinopril. He continues to require a monthly blood transfusion for chronic anemia.
Which one of the following additional treatments would improve this patient’s prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with an angiotensin-receptor blocker alone reduces mortality risk in heart failure patients, but adding losartan in a patient who already takes lisinopril would be likely to exert additional adverse effects without reducing mortality risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Digoxin can be used to treat atrial fibrillation in patients with iron overload cardiomyopathy. However, it is does not improve ventricular function or reduce mortality risk and would not address this patient’s hemochromatosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A primary-prevention implantable cardioverter-defibrillator can improve survival in patients with heart failure, but this therapy is primarily recommended for patients with heart failure and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% or less.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with secondary hemochromatosis, iron chelation therapy has been shown to improve ventricular function, reduce mortality, and prevent ventricular arrhythmias. It is used as an adjunct to conventional heart failure therapy (i.e., beta-blockers, angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin-receptor blockers).

Key learning point: The treatment that improves ventricular function and reduces mortality in patients with secondary hemochromatosis and iron overload cardiomyopathy is iron chelation therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Maintenance phlebotomy is the mainstay therapy for patients with primary hemochromatosis and an elevated serum ferritin level; it is not appropriate for those with secondary hemochromatosis (i.e., iron overload due to ineffective hematopoiesis or repetitive transfusions).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man reports a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and knee pain. His medical history is significant for hypertension and erectile dysfunction. He has distant tobacco use, minimal alcohol consumption, and no history of drug use. He has not been sexually active for the past 8 years.
On examination, his temperature is 37.5°C, his blood pressure is 134/85 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 79 beats per minute. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable liver edge at two finger breadths below the costal margin. There are no stigmata of chronic liver disease.
He has an international normalized ratio of 1.1. Other laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
14.0
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
145,000
150,000–350,000


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
8
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.8–1.3



Glucose (mg/dL)
189
<140



Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
80
0–35



Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
78
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
120
30–120


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
1.0
0.3–1.0


Tests for hepatitis B and C virus infection are negative.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to reveal this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies are most commonly considered in the setting of primary biliary cholangitis (previously referred to as primary biliary cirrhosis), a condition that is seen almost exclusively in women and usually causes alkaline phosphatase elevation.

B) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies and anti-smooth-muscle antibodies may be detected in patients with chronic liver disease of a number of etiologies, but because this patient has additional symptoms, autoimmune hepatitis is not the most likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceruloplasmin measurement, helpful when considering Wilson disease, would be of limited utility in this case, given the patient's relatively older age.

D) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies and anti-smooth-muscle antibodies may be detected in patients with chronic liver disease of a number of etiologies, but because this patient has additional symptoms, autoimmune hepatitis is not the most likely diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with hereditary hemochromatosis tend to present in middle age with unexplained fatigue, arthralgias, or end-organ damage, including cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy, diabetes, and hypogonadism (frequently manifesting as erectile dysfunction). In patients with unexplained liver disease, iron studies are useful to suggest iron overload.

HFE genotyping is commercially available and is diagnostic for hemochromatosis in patients who have abnormal iron screening studies. Homozygosity for the C282Y mutation occurs in about 5 out of every 1000 persons of northern European descent and is associated with the highest risk for liver disease. Additional mutations in HFE have also been described.

Key learning point: The combination of liver disease, arthralgia, and erectile dysfunction should prompt an evaluation for hereditary hemochromatosis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents for evaluation soon after his brother was diagnosed with hereditary hemochromatosis. The patient has no significant medical history. He reports no abdominal pain, jaundice, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, joint pain, shortness of breath, or chest pain. He does not drink alcohol.
On physical examination, his sclerae are anicteric. His cardiac examination reveals a regular rate and rhythm without evidence of murmurs, rubs, or gallops. His abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Hepatosplenomegaly is not present.
Laboratory testing reveals the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Iron (μg/dL)
200
50–150


Transferrin (mg/dL)
247
230–390



Transferrin saturation (%)
80
15–45



Ferritin (ng/mL)
859
30–300


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
32
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
27
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
47
30–120


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.4
0.3–1.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5300
4500–11,000


Hematocrit (%)
43.0
41.0–53.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
250,000
150,000–350,000


HFE mutation analysis reveals that the patient is homozygous for the C282Y mutation.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Repeat the serum ferritin level in one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeating the serum ferritin test in one year without initiating treatment would be inappropriate for a patient who already has iron overload and a genetic risk for increasing overload even further.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C should be avoided in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis, because it increases the absorption of iron.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillamine is a copper-chelating agent used in patients with Wilson disease.

D) CORRECT:

Hereditary hemochromatosis, characterized by laboratory findings suggesting elevated iron stores and confirmed with genetic testing, is usually treated with therapeutic phlebotomy. The American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases recommends the initiation of regular therapeutic phlebotomy for all patients with hereditary hemochromatosis, even those (such as this patient) who are asymptomatic and have normal liver-enzyme levels. The phlebotomy should ideally be initiated before the development of cirrhosis (to reduce morbidity and mortality) and continued until a target ferritin level of 50 to 100 ng/dL is achieved. Phlebotomy is generally safe and inexpensive.

Key learning point: Appropriate therapy for a patient with asymptomatic hereditary hemochromatosis who has elevated iron stores but normal liver enzymes is regular therapeutic phlebotomy.

E) INCORRECT:

Deferoxamine is an iron-chelating agent that is used in patients with iron overload secondary to dyserythropoietic syndromes or hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with no significant medical history reports a one-year history of fatigue and joint pain, particularly in the knuckles of the second and third fingers. The joint pain has not been associated with erythema or swelling. He also reports progressive loss of libido and erectile function during the same time period. He does not use alcohol, smoke cigarettes, or use recreational drugs.
On physical examination, his blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, his heart rate is 80 beats per minute, and his BMI is 23. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are normal. Joint examination reveals no evidence of active synovitis.
A random glucose level is 190 mg/dL (reference range, <140). Serum levels of alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase are both approximately five times above the upper limit of normal.
Hand radiographs reveal calcification of wrist cartilage.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this patient?

choices.text: Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine levels
Serum iron, iron-binding capacity, and ferritin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although patients with rheumatoid arthritis often present with involvement of the metacarpophalangeal joints, they usually have evidence of active synovitis (with erythema, warmth, and swelling). The other findings in this case (e.g., glucose intolerance, hepatic dysfunction, and hypogonadism) are more suggestive of hemochromatosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause arthralgias and reduced libido but not glucose intolerance or elevated serum aminotransferase levels. Although various endocrinopathies could explain a subset of this patient’s clinical findings, none of them account for his clinical presentation as well as hemochromatosis does.

C) CORRECT:

Hemochromatosis results from the abnormal deposition of iron in various organs. In men, the condition typically appears after age 40 or 50. The most common early symptoms include fatigue, sexual dysfunction, and arthralgias, followed by hepatic dysfunction (with elevated aminotransferases), glucose intolerance, and cardiomyopathy. Iron deposition in the pituitary gland can cause central hypogonadism. Arthropathy commonly affects the metacarpophalangeal joints, wrists, hips, and knees. Chondrocalcinosis may be seen on joint radiographs. Iron studies are usually diagnostic when hemochromatosis presents with multiple clinical manifestations.

Although various endocrinopathies could explain a subset of this patient’s clinical findings, none of them account for his clinical presentation as well as hemochromatosis does.

Key learning point: Hemochromatosis most commonly manifests in men, with typical findings including hypogonadism, arthritis, elevated serum aminotransferase levels, and glucose intolerance.

D) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome, diagnosed by measurement of 24-hour urinary free cortisol, usually causes fatigue, hyperglycemia, and reduced libido, but it also causes hypertension and other features such as weight gain, striae, and proximal myopathy. Although various endocrinopathies could explain a subset of this patient’s clinical findings, none of them account for his clinical presentation as well as hemochromatosis does.

E) INCORRECT:

Insulin-like growth factor 1 is a marker of acromegaly, which can cause glucose intolerance, reduced libido, and arthralgias, but it also typically causes hypertension and a change in hand or foot size or facial features. Although various endocrinopathies could explain a subset of this patient’s clinical findings, none of them account for his clinical presentation as well as hemochromatosis does.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man of Irish heritage was evaluated 6 months ago for type 2 diabetes, hypertension, elevated aminotransferase levels, erectile dysfunction, and soft, small testes. Mutation testing of the HFE gene confirmed the presence of a homozygous C282Y mutation, and he was initiated on a schedule of weekly therapeutic phlebotomy with removal of 500 mL of blood.
His most recent laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 11.7 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5), a ferritin level of 433 ng/mL (30–300), and a transferrin saturation of 43% (15–45). He is currently asymptomatic.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's care?

choices.text: Discontinue phlebotomy, and initiate vitamin C supplementation
Discontinue phlebotomy, and restrict dietary iron intake
Discontinue phlebotomy, and begin iron chelation therapy
Continue therapeutic phlebotomy at a reduced frequency

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although patients with hereditary hemochromatosis are at risk for hepatocellular carcinoma if they develop cirrhosis, the appropriate initial screening test would be abdominal ultrasound, not CT of the liver.

B) INCORRECT:

Initiating vitamin C supplementation would increase iron absorption, which is not indicated in a patient who already has iron overload. Furthermore, in the presence of excess iron, vitamin C becomes a free-radical generator rather than a free-radical scavenger, and serious damage to the heart and other organs can ensue.

C) INCORRECT:

Restricting dietary iron intake is not appropriate because dietary iron intake is an insignificant contributor to iron overload.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron chelation therapy, although used in other iron-overload states, is almost never required in hereditary hemochromatosis because phlebotomy is effective and inexpensive.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has hereditary hemochromatosis (HH), which is most commonly caused by mutations in the HFE gene (such as C282Y or, less commonly, H63D). HH typically manifests in middle-aged white men, often of Irish heritage. Mutation testing provides molecular confirmation of HH (including hetero-/homozygosity status) and can help with screening of family members. Therapeutic phlebotomy is the mainstay of treatment for HH and is continued until normalization of ferritin levels.

The goal ferritin level for therapeutic phlebotomy is controversial. Although some centers perform phlebotomy to achieve a ferritin level of <50 ng/mL, many patients will feel the effects of iron deficiency at this level; thus, a goal ferritin level of 50 to 100 ng/mL is a reasonable alternative. Patients with anemia may need to reduce the frequency of phlebotomy or delay therapeutic phlebotomy by a few weeks to allow their hemoglobin levels to return to baseline; once the hemoglobin level has recovered, they should resume phlebotomy.

Key learning point: Therapeutic phlebotomy for a patient with hereditary hemochromatosis should continue until the ferritin level is brought into the lower end of the normal range.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman with sickle cell disease who receives monthly red-cell transfusions to prevent sickling crises presents with fatigue.
Her blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg, her heart rate is regular and 60 beats per minute, her temperature is 37°C, and her oxygen saturation is 98% while she is breathing ambient air.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.0
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
28
36–46


Glucose (mg/dL)
210
70–100


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
120
0–35


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
210
0–35


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
3.0
0.3–1.0



Ferritin (ng/mL)
3560
30–300


Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Penicillamine is used in Wilson disease.

Ursodiol, colesevelam, penicillamine, and pancrelipase are not effective for iron overload.

B) INCORRECT:

Colesevelam is a biliary acid sequestrant.

Ursodiol, colesevelam, penicillamine, and pancrelipase are not effective for iron overload.

C) INCORRECT:

Pancrelipase is indicated in patients with pancreatic insufficiency.

Ursodiol, colesevelam, penicillamine, and pancrelipase are not effective for iron overload.

D) INCORRECT:

Ursodiol is a gallstone dissolution agent.

Ursodiol, colesevelam, penicillamine, and pancrelipase are not effective for iron overload.

E) CORRECT:

Each transfused red-cell unit introduces 200 mg to 250 mg of elemental iron into the body. Because iron is poorly excreted, the excess iron is deposited in macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system. When this iron burden overwhelms the ability of reticuloendothelial cells to sequester the iron, parenchymal iron overload develops, leading to end-organ dysfunction, especially in the liver, myocardium, and endocrine organs (causing problems such as hyperglycemia).

Iron chelation helps in the management of patients with signs of iron overload. Available treatments include deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone, all of which are effective at reducing total iron stores and preventing progression of iron overload-associated disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with transfusion-induced iron overload with evidence of end-organ dysfunction is iron chelation therapy with a treatment such as deferasirox.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man reports increasing fatigue for the past 1 month. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. His father died of liver cancer at the age of 60 years. Current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, metformin, and insulin glargine. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 116/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.6 g/dL


Serum



 Iron studies



 Iron
261 μg/dL


 Ferritin

558 ng/mL


 Transferrin saturation


83% (N = 20–50)


Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan or MRI of the abdomen may reveal evidence of iron overload but cannot differentiate primary from secondary iron overload, so a different investigation is required to confirm the diagnosis of HH. In patients with HH, a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen can be used to evaluate for hepatocellular carcinoma if a nodule > 1 cm is detected on a screening abdominal ultrasound.

B) INCORRECT:

A bone marrow biopsy is indicated if sideroblastic anemia is suspected. This condition manifests with microcytic anemia despite an iron overload, and the iron overload in sideroblastic anemia is less severe (serum ferritin levels are typically not more than 300 ng/mL).

C) INCORRECT:

Because patients with HH who develop cirrhosis have a 20–30% lifetime risk and 3–4% annual risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma, they should undergo screening ultrasonography every 6 months once cirrhosis develops. However, ultrasonography of the abdomen cannot confirm the diagnosis of HH. It also has a low sensitivity (∼ 40%) for the diagnosis of cirrhosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy was previously considered the best initial test for diagnosing HH. This test has largely been replaced by a less invasive and more specific test. In patients with confirmed HH, a liver biopsy is performed to stage the degree of fibrosis or cirrhosis and is only indicated if serum ferritin levels are > 1000 ng/mL (since the risk of cirrhosis is low if ferritin levels are below this value).

E) CORRECT:

Genetic testing is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis of HH, identify the specific genetic mutations involved, and guide management (e.g., the frequency of phlebotomy) and family screening. Genetic testing is indicated if the patient has evidence of iron overload on serum iron studies and/or has a first-degree relative with HH. HFE gene mutations, particularly C282Y and H63D mutations, are the most common cause of HH. Homozygous C282Y mutations result in clinically significant HH while a compound heterozygous mutation (C282Y/H63D) is associated with a milder disease phenotype with a low risk of complications. HH caused by non-HFE mutations is rare but severe and requires aggressive management.
questions.hint: In an adult patient with a family history of hepatocellular carcinoma, the presence of generalized fatigue, diabetes mellitus, hepatomegaly, laboratory evidence of iron overload (serum ferritin > 200 ng/mL among men or > 150 ng/mL among women, serum transferrin saturation ≥ 45%) suggest a primary iron overload, also known as hereditary hemochromatosis (HH).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of increasing fatigue and reduced libido. He also has joint pain in both of his hands. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows diffuse hyperpigmentation and decreased size of the testes. The second and third metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are tender to palpation and range of motion is limited. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Serum studies show:


Ferritin
340 ng/mL


Aspartate aminotransferase
70 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase
80 U/L


Glucose
250 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wilson disease manifests with hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases, but arthralgia, hyperpigmentation, hypogonadism, and elevated ferritin levels are not expected. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of Wilson disease, such as behavioral changes, neurological symptoms (e.g., tremor, dysarthria), and Kayser-Fleischer rings.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with liver disease (hepatomegaly, transaminitis), hypogonadism (loss of libido, testicular atrophy), diabetes mellitus (hyperglycemia), diffuse hyperpigmentation, and joint disease. These features in conjunction with elevated ferritin are suggestive of hemochromatosis.

In patients with untreated or advanced hemochromatosis, hepatocellular carcinoma can arise from progressive iron deposition in the hepatic parenchyma that results in cirrhosis. Iron deposition in cardiac tissues and subsequent fibrosis can lead to either restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome can cause fatigue, hyperpigmentation, and hyperglycemia. However, hyperpigmentation generally only occurs in areas that are not normally exposed to the sun (e.g., palm creases, oral cavity). Furthermore, proximal muscle weakness, thinning skin, weight gain, and sleep disturbances would be expected. Cushing syndrome would also not explain this patient's hepatomegaly, testicular atrophy, or elevated transaminases and ferritin levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Although symmetric arthralgias and stiffness of metacarpophalangeal joints and fatigue are common findings in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), this condition would typically also affect wrist joints and proximal interphalangeal joints, and present with joint deformities (e.g., swan neck deformity). Moreover, RA would not explain this patient's skin hyperpigmentation, diabetes mellitus, and reduced libido, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary adrenal insufficiency can cause hyperpigmentation, fatigue, and joint pain. However, in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency, decreased libido generally only occurs in women, and other signs, such as weight loss, intestinal complaints, hypotension, and/or hypoglycemia, would be present.
questions.hint: Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of the most serious complications and the most common cause of death in patients with this condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a history of beta-thalassemia, secondary hemochromatosis related to repeated blood transfusions, iron overload cardiomyopathy, and a previously documented left ventricular ejection fraction of 37% returns for evaluation. He currently takes furosemide, metoprolol succinate, and lisinopril. He continues to require a monthly blood transfusion for chronic anemia. Which one of the following additional treatments would improve this patient’s prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with an angiotensin-receptor blocker alone reduces mortality risk in heart failure patients, but adding losartan in a patient who already takes lisinopril would be likely to exert additional adverse effects without reducing mortality risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Digoxin can be used to treat atrial fibrillation in patients with iron overload cardiomyopathy. However, it is does not improve ventricular function or reduce mortality risk and would not address this patient’s hemochromatosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A primary-prevention implantable cardioverter-defibrillator can improve survival in patients with heart failure, but this therapy is primarily recommended for patients with heart failure and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% or less.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with secondary hemochromatosis, iron chelation therapy has been shown to improve ventricular function, reduce mortality, and prevent ventricular arrhythmias. It is used as an adjunct to conventional heart failure therapy (i.e., beta-blockers, angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin-receptor blockers).

Key learning point: The treatment that improves ventricular function and reduces mortality in patients with secondary hemochromatosis and iron overload cardiomyopathy is iron chelation therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Maintenance phlebotomy is the mainstay therapy for patients with primary hemochromatosis and an elevated serum ferritin level; it is not appropriate for those with secondary hemochromatosis (i.e., iron overload due to ineffective hematopoiesis or repetitive transfusions).

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the office because of fatigue and progressive pain and stiffness in her hands for the past 3 months. She used to play tennis but stopped 1 month ago because of difficulties holding the racket. Her last menstrual period was 1 year ago. She has diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows generalized hyperpigmentation. The range of motion of the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands is limited. Serum anti-nuclear antibody titers are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease is a likely complication of this patient's condition, serum calcium levels are typically normal in this condition and would not help confirm the cause of this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

A dorsopalmar x-ray of this patient's hands would likely reveal chondrocalcinosis and degenerative changes such as joint space narrowing, subchondral cysts, and the formation of hook-shaped osteophytes at the metacarpal heads. However, these changes are nonspecific and would not confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's arthropathy is most likely due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), and arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis might reveal calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals. However, synovial fluid analysis would not disclose the underlying cause of CPPD.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of fatigue, symmetric arthralgias affecting the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, skin hyperpigmentation, and diabetes mellitus suggests hemochromatosis. In premenopausal women, iron loss from menstruation can delay disease progression. In a menopausal woman like this patient, however, hemochromatosis will cause iron accumulation in multiple organs, causing symptoms as seen here. Iron studies in this patient will most likely show increased serum iron, serum ferritin, and transferrin saturation. For patients with confirmed iron overload, genetic testing for mutations of the HFE gene is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of hereditary hemochromatosis.

This patient's amenorrhea is likely to be explained by menopause as she is 51 years old, which is the average age of U.S. women at the time of menopause. Hemochromatosis itself can also lead to amenorrhea in premenopausal women because of iron-induced damage to the pituitary gland and/or gonads.

E) INCORRECT:

Testing for rheumatoid factor is performed in the screening for numerous rheumatological diseases, predominantly rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Symmetric arthralgias, stiffness in the metacarpophalangeal joints, and fatigue are common features of RA. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of RA, such as wrist and interphalangeal joint involvement, and RA would not explain this patient's skin hyperpigmentation and diabetes mellitus.
Image Description:

Symmetrical swelling of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints.
questions.hint: This patient's underlying condition puts her at increased risk for cardiomyopathy, liver cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, joint stiffness in his second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, and a new diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has bronze discoloration of his skin that has worsened over the last six months. Genetic testing confirms C282Y homozygosity in the HFE gene (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Ferritin
2,000 μg/L
20 - 300 μg/L


Transferrin saturation
65%
20 - 50%


Alanine aminotransferase
55 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L



Abdominal ultrasound: Mild hepatomegaly without focal lesions
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to prevent further organ damage?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary hemochromatosis results from increased intestinal iron absorption due to a genetic defect, not excessive dietary intake. Dietary iron restriction has minimal impact compared to the large iron burden already present. Management focuses on removing excess iron through methods like phlebotomy, as dietary changes alone are insufficient to significantly reduce iron levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Iron chelation therapy is typically reserved for transfusional iron overload, such as in beta-thalassemia major, or when phlebotomy is contraindicated. In hereditary hemochromatosis, therapeutic phlebotomy is the first-line treatment. This patient has no contraindications to phlebotomy, making chelation therapy unnecessary and not the standard approach for primary hereditary hemochromatosis.

C) CORRECT:

Therapeutic phlebotomy is the primary treatment for hereditary hemochromatosis, effectively reducing iron stores by regularly removing blood. This process mobilizes excess iron from tissues to replenish erythrocyte mass, lowering serum ferritin and transferrin saturation levels. It prevents organ damage such as liver cirrhosis, cardiac complications, and endocrine dysfunction due to iron deposition. The patient's elevated ferritin, high transferrin saturation, and C282Y homozygosity necessitate aggressive iron removal. Weekly phlebotomy is used initially until iron levels normalize, followed by maintenance therapy based on iron parameters.

Key learning point: In hereditary hemochromatosis with elevated ferritin levels, regular therapeutic phlebotomy is the standard treatment to reduce iron overload and prevent complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron accumulation in hereditary hemochromatosis is continuous, not episodic. Regular phlebotomy, often weekly or biweekly, is needed initially to reduce iron burden. Maintenance phlebotomy is based on ferritin levels, not symptom flares. Monthly phlebotomy for flares does not align with the progressive nature of iron overload in this condition.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of increasing fatigue and reduced libido. He also reports joint pain in both hands. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has diffuse hyperpigmentation and decreased testicular size. The second and third metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are tender to palpation with limited range of motion. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Serum studies show:


Ferritin, blood

340 μg/L (24–336)


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), blood

70 IU/L (15–37)


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), blood

80 IU/L (17–63)


Glucose, random, blood

13.9 mmol/L (4.0–11.0)


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wilson disease manifests with hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases, but arthralgia, hyperpigmentation, hypogonadism, and elevated ferritin levels are not expected. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of Wilson disease, such as behavioral changes, neurological symptoms (e.g., tremor, dysarthria), and Kayser-Fleischer rings.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with liver disease (hepatomegaly, transaminitis), hypogonadism (loss of libido, testicular atrophy), diabetes mellitus (hyperglycemia), diffuse hyperpigmentation, and joint disease. These features in conjunction with elevated ferritin are suggestive of hemochromatosis.

In patients with untreated or advanced hemochromatosis, hepatocellular carcinoma can arise from progressive iron deposition in the hepatic parenchyma that results in cirrhosis. Iron deposition in cardiac tissues and subsequent fibrosis can lead to either restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy.

Key learning point: Hereditary hemochromatosis is characterized by iron overload leading to liver disease, diabetes, skin hyperpigmentation, hypogonadism, and arthropathy, often with elevated ferritin and transaminases.

C) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome can cause fatigue, hyperpigmentation, and hyperglycemia. However, hyperpigmentation generally only occurs in areas that are not normally exposed to the sun (e.g., palm creases, oral cavity). Furthermore, proximal muscle weakness, thinning skin, weight gain, and sleep disturbances would be expected. Cushing syndrome would also not explain this patient's hepatomegaly, testicular atrophy, or elevated transaminases and ferritin levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Although symmetric arthralgias and stiffness of metacarpophalangeal joints and fatigue are common findings in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), this condition would typically also affect wrist joints and proximal interphalangeal joints, and present with joint deformities (e.g., swan neck deformity). Moreover, RA would not explain this patient's skin hyperpigmentation, diabetes mellitus, and reduced libido, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary adrenal insufficiency can cause hyperpigmentation, fatigue, and joint pain. However, in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency, decreased libido generally only occurs in women, and other signs, such as weight loss, intestinal complaints, hypotension, and/or hypoglycemia, would be present.
questions.hint: Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of the most serious complications and the most common cause of death in patients with this condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a history of beta-thalassemia, secondary hemochromatosis from repeated blood transfusions, iron overload cardiomyopathy, and a previously documented left ventricular ejection fraction of 37% comes to your clinic for evaluation. He is currently taking furosemide, metoprolol succinate, and lisinopril. He continues to require monthly blood transfusions for chronic anemia. Which one of the following additional treatments would improve his prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A primary-prevention implantable cardioverter-defibrillator can improve survival in patients with heart failure, but this therapy is primarily recommended for patients with heart failure and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% or less.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment with an angiotensin-receptor blocker alone reduces mortality risk in heart failure patients, but adding losartan in a patient who already takes lisinopril would be likely to exert additional adverse effects without reducing mortality risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Maintenance phlebotomy is the mainstay therapy for patients with primary hemochromatosis and an elevated serum ferritin level; it is not appropriate for those with secondary hemochromatosis (i.e., iron overload due to ineffective hematopoiesis or repetitive transfusions).

D) INCORRECT:

Digoxin can be used to treat atrial fibrillation in patients with iron overload cardiomyopathy. However, it is does not improve ventricular function or reduce mortality risk and would not address this patient’s hemochromatosis.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with secondary hemochromatosis, iron chelation therapy has been shown to improve ventricular function, reduce mortality, and prevent ventricular arrhythmias. It is used as an adjunct to conventional heart failure therapy (i.e., beta-blockers, angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin-receptor blockers).

Key learning point: The treatment that improves ventricular function and reduces mortality in patients with secondary hemochromatosis and iron overload cardiomyopathy is iron chelation therapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with fatigue and joint stiffness. Laboratory studies show serum ferritin 1200 ng/mL (normal: < 300 ng/mL) and transferrin saturation 58% (normal: < 45%). He has mild hepatomegaly and bilateral metacarpophalangeal joint tenderness. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While genetic testing confirms hereditary hemochromatosis, patients with extreme hyperferritinemia require more urgent intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Specialist consultation is important but should not delay urgent treatment. This patient's significantly elevated ferritin level indicates the need for immediate therapeutic intervention before specialist evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Iron chelation therapy is not the most appropriate initial intervention for ferritin levels that exceed 1000 ng/mL.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Patients with extreme hyperferritinemia (serum ferritin > 1000 ng/mL) should receive urgent therapeutic phlebotomy without waiting for genetic testing results.

E) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy may be indicated for staging fibrosis or investigating alternative causes of liver disease, but biopsy is not the immediate priority for this patient. The extremely elevated ferritin level necessitates urgent treatment.

questions.text: A previously healthy 44-year-old man comes to his physician because of frequent urination and increased thirst for several weeks. Physical examination shows darkened skin and a firm mass in the right upper quadrant. His blood glucose is 220 mg/dL. A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on liver biopsy is shown. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?

choices.text: Absence of a serine protease inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Upregulation of EPO and subsequent increased production of RBC is one of the causes of secondary polycythemia. Polycythemia may also present with skin changes but in the form of hyperviscosity syndrome, which causes plethora and pruritus, particularly after contact with warm water. Bronzing, diabetes mellitus and liver cirrhosis would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

The absence of β-globin chain synthesis is the cause of beta thalassemia major, which normally presents already during early childhood with severe hemolytic anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, growth retardation and skeletal deformities. Although hemolysis and subsequent transfusion in beta thalassemia major can lead to secondary hemochromatosis, this patient's age and his lack of previous medical history make this condition highly unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

An absence of α1-antitrypsin, a serine protease inhibitor, is the underlying cause of the autosomal recessive disorder α1-antitrypsin deficiency. Although patients with this condition may present with liver changes, AATD does not explain this patient's bronzed skin and urinary frequency. Additionally, α1-antitrypsin deficiency is characterized by panacinar emphysema and its manifestations (i.e., shortness of breath), which are absent in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The HFE gene codes for a membrane protein (HFE protein) that takes part in regulating iron uptake by facilitating the interaction of transferrin (and its bound iron) with its receptors. In hemochromatosis, the HFE gene is mutated; this leads to defective binding of transferrin to its receptor, which signals decreased iron stores. In response, the liver stops producing the hormone hepcidin, allowing increased iron reabsorption via unregulated ferroportin in duodenal enterocytes. The resulting iron overload leads to accumulation of bodily iron, causing manifestations such as this patient's hyperpigmented skin and diabetes mellitus. His accumulation of hepatic iron also puts him at risk of cirrhosis, which is common in cases of untreated hemochromatosis.
Image Description:

Left: Iron homeostasis is regulated by the HFE gene. HFE regulates levels of hepcidin, a protein that reduces the transport of iron from the cells to the bloodstream via the ferroportin transport protein.

Right: Hemochromatosis results from the mutation of the HFE gene → reduced hepcidin production → unregulated ferroportin activity → iron accumulation throughout the body → end-organ damage

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired binding of copper to its transporter protein (ceruloplasmin) is involved in the pathogenesis of Wilson disease. The defect is caused by autosomal recessive mutations in the ATP7B gene, which also leads to impaired biliary copper excretion. The result is an increase in free serum copper and subsequent bodily accumulation. Copper accumulation within major organs results in characteristic clinical features including hepatic damage, CNS manifestations (dysarthria, dystonia, parkinsonism), renal damage (urinary frequency, urgency), and Kayser-Fleischer rings. Although this patient has increased urination and hepatic findings, these are most likely due to hemochromatosis, which does not play a role in copper metabolism.
Image Description:

Left (physiologic):
(1) Copper ions are absorbed in the intestine and transported via the portal vein to the liver sinusoids, where they are taken up by the hepatocytes. (2) In the hepatocytes, copper ions enter the Golgi complex via the Wilson protein (ATP7B). (3) In the Golgi complex, the copper ions bind to apoceruloplasmin, thereby forming ceruloplasmin. (4) Excess copper is excreted into the bile via the Wilson protein. (5) Ceruloplasmin is secreted into plasma and spread throughout the body. (6) A small amount of unbound copper ions passes directly into the blood and is available as free serum copper.

Right (Wilson disease):
In Wilson disease, the Wilson protein is dysfunctional. Copper ions can neither be taken up by the Golgi complex (3) nor excreted into the bile (4). As a result, copper ions accumulate in the hepatocytes, which leads to hepatic damage. A large amount of excess, unbound copper ions passes directly into the bloodstream (6) raising the free serum copper concentration. This results in copper deposition in other organs.
questions.hint: This patient's darkened skin and signs of diabetes mellitus (hyperglycemia, increased thirst and urination) should raise suspicion of hemochromatosis. Biopsy findings showing periportal hepatocytes with brownish yellow color, which indicates iron accumulation, is characteristic of the condition.
